pros: There is much flexibility for time management at work.

pros: UMB is a state-sponsored university.
cons:
The leadership has got the wrong understanding that what makes a university to thrive is 'just' the NIH funding. They do not believe in any other type of funding as a factor for promotion simply because non-NIH funding is not counted towards the Medical Schools national ranking. 
UMB constructed a new beautiful building for research purposes, which remained empty for quite some time. The reason was that the Dean wanted new hires to be located in the new building. This clearly was insulting to the current researchers who had to endure the old infrastructure. 
As a former employee, I never got a chance for an exit interview. The only communication I got from UMB after I left was a text message, asking to provide any comments I have about UMB!!!
I received several major NIH, Foundation, and Society funding during my limited time at UMB and purchased various high-end equipment using these funds. The UMB held them all upon my departure, further proving that the mindset of leadership is that the instruments will generate ideas to obtain more funding and not the researchers. 
If you are a talented researcher I highly recommend finding a more collaborative environment to start your career. Your achievements will not be seen or appreciated unless you are connected to big guys of the leadership.

pros: Nice environment in central Baltimore
cons: Central Baltimore can be sketchy when working long hours

review_title: Rules apply to everyone but leadership
pros: Excellent benefits. Depending on where you work the people are great and the work is important. Salaries are market rate and competitive.
cons: Management and leadership hire their nieces/nephews/neighbors/spouses/friends kids. Commitment to diversity is a farce when they only want to hire people in their own networks. Core values are more aspirational than reflective of actual actions. Commitment to flexible work is in word only in some units - the employees know they'll be treated differently if they express interest in that. Leadership holds the University back from being truly great, innovative, and supportive of diversity and inclusion.

pros: Prior to the merge with UMMS, working at Upper Chesapeake Medical Center was such a pleasure! The people were like family. My coworkers were very helpful & there was such comradely. Work day was very flexible which allowed for optimum work-life balance. Requesting time off was never an issue. There was open communication with management with such ease!
cons: However with the transition over to the health system-UMMS, there was no longer flexible work schedules with poor communication among management & employees. Requesting time off was a hassle - many times requests were denied, which inevitably affected work-life balance in a negative way. Corporate work environment was just not same. Unfortunately the merge with UMMS had a very negative impact! As a result there have been many job openings for inpatient coders! Beware of this!

pros: Decent pay, great benefits, nice colleagues. There are some employees that really want to help save the organization from going under. If you get shot or stabbed, they'll save your life here.
cons: About 10-15 years behind in certain ways in comparison to other health systems in the area. Old building...needs many updates. Horrible executive leadership. Some have caused Dimensions's financial demise but are still working there. Unethical business practices. Not enough staff to implement positive ideas. Poor physician satisfaction.

review_title: Good place to be a graduate student if you can get into a lab with funding
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Baltimore, MD
pros: As of the last few years, there are lots of career development seminars and opportunities for students and postdocs to explore careers outside of academia. The campus is nice and well-maintained. Lab facilities and cores are top-notch. Flexibility and work environment depend entirely on your mentor, but it's been a great experience for me.
cons: Security is kind of iffy. There have been some problems with thefts from labs, despite security guards at most entrances. Campus could be safer overall; the campus police are really trying, but the campus is in an area that makes security tough. I also worry that they're admitting too many grad students for how many labs can afford to take them. Funding is so scarce and I've heard from newer grad students that they're having trouble finding labs.

job_title: Histology Technician in Bel Air, MD
pros: Small hospital. Not a punitive environment. Will help you learn and grow
cons:
More than one person can not be off at a time even when over staffed. Time Employees have to put in for summer vacation in January. Your only allowed 2 weeks and most time they can not be consecutive. Only 2 days off during the Christmas and New Years holidays. They do not tap into individual strengths to assign special projects. They do not offer or encourage professional development training except for generic webinars and emailed articles. Not allowed to attend Tumor conferences or anything else that the hospital may offer in way of personal and professional enrichment.
Employees are worked like a mule- 7.5 hours, one 15 min break and one .30 lunch. If you are a life learner, love flexibility and want to spend time with family, this isn’t the place for you. Burn out. You eventually will just feel like a brainless robot.

job_title: Environmental Service Aide in Bel Air, MD
pros: You get to meet a lot of interesting people
cons: The management will throw you under the bus as fast as they can when something goes wrong even when they instructed you to preform the act that got you thrown under the bus to begin with.  Overall staff (Nurses, Techs, Docs) are more often then not, racist and are known to make racist or stereotypical comments and or assumptions. Also, most staff looks down on EVS workers and view you as beneath them and will talk to down to you as if your a child. Dont work at Upper Chesapeake in Evs if you are a minority or a democrat. Try to work in a high position. there is a lot of foolishness with this hospital.

job_title: Research Laboratory Supervisor in Baltimore, MD
pros: The University of Maryland under the leadership of Dr Perman has been growing. More focus in advancing and helping the community around campus. So many programs for staff, students and faculty to increase in knowledge and experience (this worth money when you add to your resume). My direct supervisor is very supportive and appreciative for my work.
cons: Academic environment is under the huge pressure of scarce funding. UMB is not different. It a struggle to reach to the next year. So many good researchers are struggling to get grants, some had to leave already because of funding situation.

review_title: Horrible, not fulfilling, lack of resources,
pros: Leadership at Laurel Regional Hospital, Potential UMMS affiliation, Bowie Health Campus, dedicated employees with tenure, Cafe at Laurel Regional Hospital
cons: Finance leadership, lack of communication, lack of departmental knowledge, lack of basic finance skills, no organization, 25 day month end close process, no processes or procedures, no vision to improve or change processes, ideas and visions go ignored

review_title: Sad, sad, place that thinks it is very cutting edge and important. It is not.
pros: As a staff person; not a student: No oversite and management doesn't care about quality of work. This was distressing at first, but when I figured out that I was the ONLY person who cared about quality and doing a good job, it became pointless to continue trying. After adopting the "I don't care attitude" of the rest of the campus, life became a breeze.
cons: The people who actually run the university; the clerical help, HR,  and the business office people are typical Baltimore city born and bred and "educated." They think they are professional and smart, but they are not. It is a culture of incompetence and entitlement. If you actually want to get something done, they will make your life a living hell.

review_title: Its a survival for the fitess
pros: I like the location because it is close to work. The floors on every unit is well stock with supplies for the patients and supply coffee for everyone
cons: Don't pay enough, the nurses are lazy and don't do team work at all.  under staff and work short most of the time and bonuses foe people who work overtime and come in too work when you are very short

review_title: Great benefits and work environment; not good for career growth
pros:
Benefits are totally awesome and it's probably the main reason you'll find it hard to leave
People are generally nice and just come in to do their time and leave and live their lives
Education benefit, vacation days, paid time off is very generous and fun events on campus
Pay is better than Hopkins but we've been on clampdown last few years
cons: Bad for growth and advancement, unless you're in the white women's club. I've seen others get promoted while I've been here working faithfully year after year. The only way to advance since the last few years of budget woes is to get a reclass, or try to seek another position in another department.

review_title: Struggling Healthcare System Due to Flawed Management Culture
pros: CEO John Spearman, is very professional.
cons: Needs to restructure management - especially Directors, and Managers.  Many of them do not buy into the CEO's leadership values.  The resistance is strong for those in key positions.   There is very little consideration for who is hired for what positions.   There are leaders (especially managers and directors)  "trying to learn as they go along" but fall short....therefore the bar remains low - maintaining yesterday's norm.   And I'm  talking about the lack of basic functional skills.   It's sad.

review_title: Good Work Environment, Potential for Growth
job_title: Instructional Technology Specialist in Baltimore, MD
pros: I think it depends on the program or department you work in. I'm lucky that the program I work in has leadership that values staff growth and development and that sets the tone for middle management, who provide direct supervision of staff, to follow suit.
cons: Some university processes are bogged down by bureaucracy and can drag out the timeframe of moving from request to implementation. Reliance on grant funding can limit the ability to be responsive to new and emerging needs.

review_title: Above average facility features with typical subpar management
job_title: Registered Nurse in Bel Air, MD
pros: For community hospital, facility has many ox the features of the big name hospitals; nutrition services best ive seen in a hospital, supplies and pharmacy also excellent (until covid of course)
cons: Suffers from the common problems at most hospitals—poor management/obsession with ever changing metrics without necessary supports. The covid choices made (And didn’t make) completely obliterated all the leadership credibility. The problems are common issues for hospital RNs but what went down during covid—had to leave

pros: I have never been or seen people so poorly treated in my life.  The Procurement Department is managed or not managed by a half wit who has been there for 30 years, who appears to have no real relationship, professional or personal, as he is just a broken human being.  The environment is toxic and should be avoided at all cost.  The University has allowed this to go on for 30 years.  Pathetic.  The problems are so severe that they have problems keeping employees in a place with great benefits, time off and retirement.  That says it all.  These systematic issues will take years to solve, if they ever recognize there is a problem.  Shameful!!
cons:
Benefits
Time-Off

Who cares if the job is the worst ever!!!

job_title: CNA/Patient Care Tech/OR Surgical Scrub Tech in Bel Air, MD
pros:
Admin would always listen and support staff,  great pay, great doctors to work with,  great benefits,  everyone  worked as a team. I worked L&DUnit,  Mom/Baby & Peds Unit,  and Phlebetomy/Lab.
Had alternatives for health care/ holistic approaches.  Also had days for massage therapy for staff member that actually worked on  the units!! That was a great thing!!
cons: None at the time I worked there.

pros:
The benefits are great! Health, dental, retirement, life, disability, etc, but the best part is the pto - at least for my full time salaried administrative position, I started off with 25 days. That's 5 weeks y'all!! 

There are also attempts to raise the hospital from the ashes (speaking specifically about Prince George's Hospital Center). Slooooowly but surely. Ok, not surely... Possibly maybe...? At least in a few years the University of Maryland system is taking over... But it keeps being pushed back.
cons: The environment of apathy is so ingrained here that it's really hard to see anything changing. The employees who have been there a long time have been conditioned to accept that lack of hard work, empathy or compassion do not result in any consequences. If you're a person who is brought in subscribing to the notion that things are changing, you're going to have a struggle here. Which is not to say that the good fight is not there to be fought... You just have to understand what a truly uphill battle it is going to be. Also, my title refers specifically to the subsection of employment under DHA (Dimensions Healthcare Associates), the "physician practice" side of operations. The executive in charge of DHA has zero clue what he is doing. Meetings with him make you feel like you're on a very bad trip. He talks in circles, forgets things on the reg (even though he appears to be writing everything down), and contradicts himself on a daily basis. I know for a fact he is the main reason for a number of resignations recently.

pros:
There is really no pressure to get anything done. 
Fringe benefit (healthcare, tuition remission, vacation)
cons:
Check any ambition you have at the door. No pressure means that there are not clear objectives. Put a premium on appearance that everything is great.
Everyone is focused on politics. Whom can you give a small grant so that I can get a favor later.
Forget getting promotions or pay raises, those are saved for executives. You can count on the 1-3% pay raise every time there is an election.
No clear defined rolls. As a result, people are stepping on each others responsibilities. Makes it easy to not take responsibility for anything,

pros: The benefits were great. You get health insurance, dental insurance, retirement, and they even give you, your spouse and a dependent free tuition to any university of MD college. Also the job itself is very easy.
cons: They pay was not good. I was making just under $11 an hour. It also takes time to get a set schedule and a permanent security post, so expect to be moved around quite a bit. Also there is little room for advancement in security. There are only two levels to this job: security officers and supervisors. However, they do work alongside university police and you can be promoted through the police department, or another state of Maryland position.

pros: The drive isn't too bad since I live in the same county.  If you want a short commute in the county and only a pay check, apply here.
cons: Horrible environment to work in, bosses say they care about employees but they really do not, ideas are not appreciated, just go in and do your job with your head down and mouth shut and you will get by, personal growth is not encouraged, additional training to improve yourself is not available, cut tuition reimbursement severely, benefits are the worst, raises are ridiculous, favoritism is the slogan, not team work.  Look somewhere else for work.

pros: Benefits is the good thing about this job
cons: Everything else is pretty much in my description btu this job is a job where jobs go to die

pros:
The benefit is very good which include paid 2 weeks vacation, sick leaves, etc
Flexible hours, I can choose my own schedule which is pretty neat.
Great employee, I love the people I work with, great spirit, motivated and hard working.
Awesome boss
Located in downtown baltimore
cons:
Traffic can be very bad especially during business hours.
No free packing. Had to pay a monthly fee for packing. 
Cafeteria food is expensive. I advise bringing your food from home.

review_title: Stay far away from this place
job_title: Floor Technician in Bel Air, MD
pros: About the only good thing is that I get a steady pay check and it is full time.
cons: Incompetent management, no team work, racism is alive and well in this place,  Management says negative and demeaning things about employees to other employees. There is no team work here and the management is extremely ineffective. McDonald's or Walmart is a better employer than this hospital. I dread going to work everyday

pros: Best mentorship. Grow their employees within. Best leadership. CEO always keeps employees informed of all that is happening current and future so no surprises. very family oriented and like a second family. will always be indebted to and love my first real career family!! VP of HR is the best leader and stays involved right beside CEO. Patient and Family first!! Look thru patients eyes as if we or our family is laying there bc most likely it's bound to happen there! Will always go back if opportunity/need approaches! They take very good care of their employees!!! Top notch!
cons: Could have more support for alternative and holistic modalities for team and patients as that seems to be first budget cut.

pros: The best part of working at Maryland law was the people. Everyone was vested in everyone being successful. The quality of students helps drive quality faculty and staff.
cons: If you are not a professor, they do not pay market rates or even come close. If you are after making good money, stay away. It does not get better with time.

pros:
The University had/has a number of excellent high tech equipment if you can find people willing to share or train you on the equipment. 
Many labs are interactive, but you often have to seek out interactions to build collaborations, just as you would at any other institution. There are also a good many researchers in diverse fields to collaborate with if you are interested in trying new techniques. It also has one of the few BSL-3 labs in the country if you are interested in pathogen research.
cons:
Crime is extremely high in the area and I was advised to get a police escort to my car if I worked late. This environment hampers research because often experiments are not a 9 to 5  sort of thing. I was confronted by a very unstable individual outside of the building I worked in and when I talked to the security guard, they could not have cared less. This showed me that the guards are there just for show, not to help people out. 
It was very expensive for parking and for medical insurance so as a post-doc you are not able to pay off your student loans even though you're not a student any more. If there is damaging conflict within your lab, there really isn't anyone who can address it. Conflict resolution is pretty much so null and void at this institution, so choose wisely when entering a lab.

review_title: Company with lots of potential but lacks disciplined leadership and strategic direction
pros: Recent change at the CEO position is very promising, encouraging and a "light at the end of the tunnel". Employees are friendly and welcoming.
cons: Lack of executive leadership, strategic plan and accountability as an organization. Lack of urgency, will and discipline (especially by the leadership) to enact change and reverse negative fiscal situation

review_title: Management is very supportive of education and personal growth as well as home/work balance.
job_title: Registered Nurse in Havre de Grace, MD
pros: Very supportive and encouraging of continuing education and home/work balance. Flexible with scheduling.
cons: Some charge nurses need a little more experience. Team members need to work on gossip, as with all workplaces. Team members should hold each other accountable more often.

review_title: The PHSR Department in School of Pharmacy is a good place to work at
job_title: Research Staff (Functional Title) in Baltimore, MD
pros: Great benefits -- tuition remission, paid leave, etc. Great people -- motivated, intelligent, professional, open-minded, friendly. Strong focus on learning -- many opportunities to do new things, to be mentored, and to learn. Strong focus on achievement -- it is important to get the work done and there is a lot of flexibility and freedom about when and how one will work.
cons: Few or no opportunities for promotion if you are a research staff person.

pros: The people are mostly professional, the work is ever changing (different equipment needing repair), the state benefits are nice, it is familiar and I am good at my job.
cons: The job can be political, people advanced not necessarily based on ability but how well they talk to management.

review_title: Incredibly stressful but overall worth it
pros: State of the art facilities, incredible research opportunities, and rigorous coursework to make you an expert in your field.
cons: The first year is so incredibly stressful to the point where students are struggling to cope. The Parking on campus is awful, and the location can be unsafe. The shuttle system is also terrible.

review_title: Very satisfying experience compared to some of the places I have worked previously.
pros: People care about each other.  Friendly atmosphere.  Desire to be the best.  Well managed from a business perspective.  Opportunities to grow.  Good future potential in light of the coming merger with University of Maryland Medical System.
cons: Too lenient at times with poor behaviors.  Too focused on growing from within.  Need to bring in more outside people to bring in new ideas.

job_title: Appeals Specialist in Silver Spring, MD
pros:
My first Manager was the best.
Certificate programs are available (paid for by company).
Professionalism
cons:
In some instances salary not commensurate with qualifications.
'Team work' is not necessarily there
Favorite

review_title: University of Maryland--A Good Place to Work
job_title: Manager, Technology Training in Baltimore, MD
pros:
Competitive salaries
Excellent benefits
A lot of time flexibility
cons: In many job roles one can get a higher salary in private industry than at the University, but typically the hours are longer and the work more demanding.

review_title: It was a professional and healthy environment to work in.  Work was done as a team including other professional such as
pros: Working at Dimensions Healthcare System gave me the opportunity to interact with people of different cultures, including patients, and that gave me a sense of diversity
cons: There is a need to improve on patient satisfaction and everyone as a part to play.

review_title: Look elsewhere if you want to be happy (as a tech)
job_title: Patient Care Technician in Havre de Grace, MD
pros: paid time off- holidays, sick, personal, vacation
cons: EXTREMELY understaffed especially for techs. low wages. unfair treatment of loyal employees.

pros: Literally none. Please see cons below.
cons: First, just hope your paycheck never gets messed up. You will lose your sanity trying to get it fixed, doesn’t matter if you did nothing wrong. Communication in this place is a joke, it's an "everyone for themselves" attitude, departments don't want to help each other. You may be inspired to join the cause of bettering the health care for Prince George's County residents, I was,  but it's unfortunately a lost cause with this hospital. You have to be a literal saint to accomplish that.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Baltimore, MD
pros: The graduate programs are generally supportive and willing to  listen to student's feedback.
cons: Many of the principal investigators on campus have a negative attitude about graduate students being involved in anything but lab work or interested in a career other than academia. That said, there are a few PIs on campus who are very supportive of all students' ambitions and the higher offices (i.e. the president's office) is also very supportive of "alternative" career paths.

review_title: Wonderful Organization  now a part of University of Maryland Medical System
pros: Formerly Dimensions Healthcare but now UM Capital Region has amazing leadership in place and working hard to truly improve healthcare for the residents of Prince Georges County.
cons: Salaries continue to be a challenge not competitive  in the DC Market

review_title: Good benefits, Secure Job, Very low Pay
pros: Good benefits, relatively secure position once a state employee
cons: Pay is significantly lower compared to national average. The university has had a pay rise freeze for the past 6 years. No room for growth, too much bureaucracy.

pros: The benefits package is tremendous
cons: The administration is so poor the university barely functions. Mistakes in payroll, lack of response from government departments in general exasperate the already poor admin structure at the University. There are way too many staff members doing way to little work. It's a confusing mess in general. The department i worked for was one of the best at the university and the people were very friendly but the difficulty in getting anything processed or addressed through admin was so bad that i went for years with open issues that were flatly ignored.

pros: I was able to help patients to ensure that the patient was register into the system, so that they can be seen by a physician
cons: I felt like I was not appreciated for my work performancce, and was let go on an unfaithful fired.

review_title: Very educational worth the time and effort
job_title: Systems Technical Specialist in Cheverly, MD
pros: Opportunities develop quickly, somewhat endless if you choose
cons: Organization has not given a raise to their employees in over 2 years

pros: If you are interested in clinical research there can be good networking opportunities.  Seems less cut throat and friendlier than other places. In the centre of the city so is very easy to access.
cons: Poor mentorship, little institutional support, isolated research environment.  Pay is lower than other institutions in Baltimore. Employer does not cover medical insurance which the other major university in Baltimore does.

pros: Good location in Harford County
cons: Upper management and Human Resources are nonresponsive to concerns of employees regarding consistent abusive practices and treatment of employees by managers and directors.  There are no consequences for department leaders who fail to meet objectives year after year.

review_title: CDI at UM Capital Region Health
job_title: Clinical Documentation Specialist in Baltimore, MD
pros: Great team, great learning experience, good place to develop yourself
cons: A lot of turn over. CDI is part of the quality department and not HIM, so the scope of responsibilities is different. There is a lot asked of CDIs beyond the normal scope of a CDI. These things aren't necessarily cons just depends on what your comfortable with.

pros: Johns Hopkins is very close by.  Some of my colleagues in other labs around campus have had more positive experiences than mine.
cons: While working here, I feel a nearly constant struggle to maintain my personal ethics.  The university has also done everything it can to mess up my salary, including cutting it for the first three months I worked here, and misfiling my tax withdrawals, leading to a $1000 tax bill at the end of the year.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Bel Air, MD
pros: True teamwork, collaboration among staff and physicians, access to all specialties, tuition reimbursement, salary and benefits are competitive, free parking and shuttle, and excellent group of people to work with.
cons: Growing pains of a once small community hospital that is expanding in a good way.

review_title: Assistant Professor at University of Maryland School of Medicine
pros: They offer good benefit package.
cons: Not a supportive environment for principal investigators as they are second or even third class citizens to staff, administrators, and of course MDs.

pros: It is a great environment to work, the faculty are nurturing and the collaborative nature of the department makes communication seamless.
cons: some times  experiments don't work out and that can hinder your project which is really frustrating.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bel Air, MD
pros: I love my manager. She checks up on me as far as schooling and my career goals. My coworker are all pretty friendly, driven, and family oriented. So pretty much all like minded.
cons: Can get overwhelming but there are certainly more good days than bad. No benefits whatsoever as PRN.

pros: I was able to provide healthcare to people that really needed it, which made me feel good.
cons: Political, lack of information and money to accomplish the mission.

pros: Benefits, salary, supportive environment, access to networking and professional development

job_title: Research Project Coordinator in Baltimore, MD
pros: Pleasant work environment. The school is conveniently located downtown and easy to access. Great way to network and build rapport with well established people in the academic and nursing fields.

review_title: Nice place to work. Supervisor,s not professional but I miss being there.
pros: Where it's located, BENIFITS are pretty good, they pay for schooling. You Are Off On weekends, AND ALOT Of Holidays off.

pros: The supervisors are both experienced and helpful. The work-life balance was excellent, and overall you have a great learning environment if you are a recent professional.
cons: Working in a small office did not allow for many networking opportunities outside of work. Political culture among the staff.

pros: Health benefits,  Locations,  Good co-workers, education benefits (only if studying something relevant to the hospital ).

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Clarksville, MD
pros: People there including nurses, doctors and software engineer are nice to work with. There are many opportunities to learn domain knowledge and new technology. Nice pay for GRA.
cons: Sometimes work overtime. No or limited room to promote. Other than that, it is a pretty good work place.

pros: Good place to cut your teeth in the field.
cons: Antiquated legacy systems. Lack of involvement of staff in key areas of growth and development

pros: There were none at all

pros: Comfortable weather zone, close to the national capital, fast job growing area

pros: Leadership is engaged and active; Managers/directors care about their employees and want them to succeed even if that means expanding their careers in a different department.
